sections.text: Use this structure when someone else does something for you (you arrange or pay for a service).

examples: I repaired my car ‚Üí I had my car repaired
She cuts her hair ‚Üí She has her hair cut

sections.text: Active: I repaired my car (I did it myself). Causative: I had my car repaired (someone else did it for me).

examples.original: The mechanic is servicing my car this afternoon.
examples.hint: Think: Who is doing the action? Not me - the mechanic. Use 'am having + car + serviced'

examples.original: A professional photographer took our wedding photographs.
examples.hint: The photographer did it for us. Structure: had + photographs + taken

examples.original: The dentist is going to remove my wisdom teeth next week.
examples.hint: The dentist will do it (not me). Use: am having + teeth + removed

examples.original: An electrician should check the wiring regularly.
examples.hint: An electrician does the checking. Structure: should have + wiring + checked

examples.original: A decorator painted our living room last month.
examples.hint: The decorator did it for us. Use: had + living room + painted

examples.original: The hairdresser is cutting my hair tomorrow morning.
examples.hint: You can also use 'get' instead of 'have'. Structure: am getting + hair + cut

examples.original: Someone should repair the broken window immediately.
examples.hint: Someone else will repair it. Use: have + window + repaired

examples.original: A qualified plumber is installing the system.
examples.hint: Present continuous causative: are having + system + installed

examples.original: The optician tested my eyes last Tuesday.
examples.hint: The optician did the test. Past causative: had + eyes + tested

examples.original: A specialist surgeon performed the operation.
examples.hint: The surgeon performed it. Structure: had + operation + performed

sections.text: Use when reporting what people say, think, or believe - especially in formal contexts like news reports.

examples: People say he is rich ‚Üí He is said to be rich
Everyone thinks she left ‚Üí She is thought to have left

sections.text: Same time: is said to be. Earlier time: is said to have + past participle.
examples: People say she IS ill ‚Üí She is said to be ill
People say she WAS ill ‚Üí She is said to have been ill

examples.original: People say that the minister is planning to resign.
examples.hint: Same time (is planning). Use: is said to be + -ing form

examples.original: Everyone believes that the painting is a genuine Rembrandt.
examples.hint: Same time (is). Use: is believed to be

examples.original: People think that the company lost millions in the scandal.
examples.hint: Earlier time (lost - past). Use: is thought to have + past participle

examples.original: Everyone knows that the director has resigned from the board.
examples.hint: Earlier action (has resigned). Use: is known to have + past participle

examples.original: People believe that the prisoner escaped through a tunnel.
examples.hint: Past action (escaped). Use: is believed to have + past participle

examples.original: People say that the actress is dating a famous footballer.
examples.hint: Same time (is dating). Use: is said to be + -ing form

examples.original: People report that the celebrity is living in Switzerland.
examples.hint: Same time (is living). Use: is reported to be + -ing form

examples.original: People consider that artist to be a genius.
examples.hint: Same time (is). Use: is considered to be

examples.original: Everyone thinks that the athlete broke the world record deliberately.
examples.hint: Past action (broke). Use: is thought to have + past participle

examples.original: Everyone believes that the politician accepted bribes.
examples.hint: Past action (accepted). Use: is believed to have + past participle

sections.text: Use passive voice when the action is more important than who does it, or when the doer is unknown or obvious.

examples: They repair cars ‚Üí Cars are repaired
Someone cleans the office ‚Üí The office is cleaned
They are building a house ‚Üí A house is being built
Someone is repairing the road ‚Üí The road is being repaired
They will announce results ‚Üí Results will be announced
Someone will finish it ‚Üí It will be finished

examples.original: They are building a new shopping centre in the town.
examples.hint: Present continuous passive: is + being + past participle (built)

examples.original: They will announce the exam results next Friday.
examples.hint: Future simple passive: will + be + past participle (announced)

examples.original: The council is repairing the road outside our house.
examples.hint: Present continuous passive: is + being + past participle (repaired)

examples.original: They are going to demolish the old cinema next month.
examples.hint: Future with 'going to': is going to be + past participle (demolished)

examples.original: The waiter is taking our food to the wrong table.
examples.hint: Present continuous passive: is + being + past participle (taken)

examples.original: They are examining the proposal very carefully.
examples.hint: Present continuous passive: is + being + past participle (examined)

examples.original: They are currently renovating the town hall.
examples.hint: Present continuous passive: is + being + past participle (renovated)

examples.original: The committee will discuss the proposal at tomorrow's meeting.
examples.hint: Future simple passive: will + be + past participle (discussed)

examples.original: You must complete the application form in black ink.
examples.hint: Modal passive: must + be + past participle (completed)

examples.original: The chef was preparing our meal when we arrived.
examples.hint: Past continuous passive: was + being + past participle (prepared)

examples: They arrested him ‚Üí He was arrested
Someone stole my bike ‚Üí My bike was stolen
They have repaired it ‚Üí It has been repaired
Someone has stolen my phone ‚Üí My phone has been stolen
They had finished it ‚Üí It had been finished
Someone had sold the house ‚Üí The house had been sold

examples.original: Someone has stolen my bicycle from outside the library.
examples.hint: Present perfect passive: has + been + past participle (stolen)

examples.original: The police arrested the burglars last night.
examples.hint: Past simple passive: were + past participle (arrested)

examples.original: Someone had already sold the house when we enquired.
examples.hint: Past perfect passive: had + been + past participle (sold)

examples.original: Somebody must have taken my umbrella by mistake.
examples.hint: Modal perfect passive: must have + been + past participle (taken)

examples.original: The fire brigade rescued the cat from the tree.
examples.after: the tree by the fire brigade.
examples.hint: Past simple passive: was + past participle (rescued)

examples.original: They cancelled all flights because of the snow.
examples.hint: Past simple passive: were + past participle (cancelled). Note: 'because of' changes to 'due to'

examples.original: They had decorated the hall beautifully for the wedding.
examples.hint: Past perfect passive: had + been + past participle (decorated)

examples.original: Someone stole my laptop whilst I was having lunch.
examples.hint: This is causative, but unwanted! Structure: had + laptop + stolen

examples.original: Someone had left the gate open and the dog escaped.
examples.hint: Past perfect passive: had + been + past participle (left)

examples.original: The manager should have informed the staff about the changes.
examples.hint: Modal perfect passive: should have + been + past participle (informed)

sections.text: This section mixes all the passive structures you've learned: causative, reporting, and different tenses.
Causative: have + object + past participle. Reporting: is said/thought + to + infinitive. Simple: be + past participle.

examples.original: My brother is repairing the computer for me this evening.
examples.hint: Causative with 'get'. Structure: am getting + computer + repaired

examples.original: People say that house prices are falling rapidly.
examples.hint: Reporting structure, same time. Use: are said to be + -ing form

examples.original: Someone has to mend the broken fence urgently.
examples.answer: have to get the broken fence
examples.hint: Causative with modal. Structure: have to get + fence + mended

examples.original: People know that the actor owns several properties abroad.
examples.hint: Reporting structure, same time. Use: is known to own (present simple stays as infinitive)

examples.original: Everyone thinks that the team will win the championship.
examples.answer: is thought to be going to win
examples.hint: Reporting structure with future. Use: is thought to be going to win

examples.original: My neighbour is fixing the puncture in my bicycle tyre.
examples.hint: Causative present continuous. Structure: am getting + puncture + fixed

examples.original: People say that pollution levels have risen dramatically.
examples.hint: Reporting structure, earlier time. Use: are said to have + past participle

examples.original: A professional photographer should take your photo.
examples.hint: Causative with modal. Structure: should have + photo + taken

examples.original: People report that the company is facing bankruptcy.
examples.hint: Reporting structure, same time. Use: is reported to be + -ing form

examples.original: Someone ough to clean these windows soon.
examples.hint: Modal passive. Note: 'ough' is a typo for 'ought'. Structure: ought to be + past participle
